Added guidance in IRM 5.7.5.3.1(7) that TFRP nonassertions based on collectibility do not require submission to CPM.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This material supersedes IRM 5.7.5, dated June 28, 2011.

) As part of the collectibility investigation, current compliance with IMF filing re- quirements will be verified. (
) The following factors will be considered when determining collectibility of the TFRP: to (cid:
) Current financial condition (cid:
) Involvement in a bankruptcy proceeding (cid:
) Income history and future income potential (cid:
) Asset potential (likelihood of increase in equity in assets and taxpayer’s potential to acquire assets in the future)

(2) Research the taxpayer’s information by using the following internal and external sources, as well as any other applicable sources, to verify and determine collectibility: To Verify: Use the Following Source(s): Income IRPTR and Employment Records Income and assets, e.g., income RTVUE or BRTVUE tax interest deduction for real property, IRA contributions, etc. Addresses INOLE Motor Vehicles Motor Vehicle Records Real Estate Property Records

Below are guidelines to assist in determining whether to assert the penalty based on collectibility:

If responsible person Then. . . financial analysis shows. . . Any present or future ability Assess the penalty and take the ap- to pay propriate collection action based on an analysis of the taxpayer’s financial condition. No present, but future ability Assess the TFRP based on future to pay income potential and possible refund offset. Prepare a pre-assessed Form 53 and file lien if appropriate. The responsible person Assess the TFRP since there is a cannot be located or good possibility of some collection contacted but internal from the assets/income sources that research identifies assets or were located. income sources No present or future income Do not assess the TFRP since the potential exists over the col- financial analysis shows there is little lection statute period prospect that the taxpayer will receive any increase in income or acquire assets that will enable the Service to collect any of the penalty.

Do not assess the TFRP since the financial analysis shows there is little prospect that the taxpayer will receive any increase in income or acquire assets that will enable the Service to collect any of the penalty.

in the balance due case file. (
) Nonassertion of the penalty should be recommended if a responsible person cannot be located, nor can any assets or income sources be located. (
) Assertion of the penalty should be recommended if the responsible person cannot be located but assets or income sources can be located. (

) If the TIN of the responsible party is unknown but assertion of the TFRP is still being recommended, contact the Entity Control unit at the appropriate Campus to have an Internal Revenue Service Number (IRSN) assigned (See IRM

, Internal Revenue Service Number (IRSN) Format). In order to establish the account you will need to provide the initiator’s name, address, and phone number, the purpose for which the number is needed (TFRP as- sessment), and the following information on the taxpayer:
Include one copy of Form 9327 with the TFRP file. Include a copy of Form 9327 with a copy of the approved Form 4183 in the balance due case file.
Nonassertion of the penalty should be recommended if a responsible cannot be located, nor can any assets or income sources be located.
Assertion of the penalty should be recommended if the responsible person cannot be located but assets or income sources can be located.

If the TIN of the responsible party is unknown but assertion of the TFRP is being recommended, contact the Entity Control unit at the appropriate to have an Internal Revenue Service Number (IRSN) assigned (See IRM 3.13.5.22, Internal Revenue Service Number (IRSN) Format). In order to establish the account you will need to provide the initiator’s name, address, and phone number, the purpose for which the number is needed (TFRP as- sessment), and the following information on the taxpayer:
) If the present collection potential is minimal but future collection potential exists: a. Recommend assertion of the TFRP for group manager approval.
b. Advise the taxpayer that one notice will be sent reflecting the balance and a Notice of Federal Tax Lien will be filed, if appropriate. c. Prepare Form
, Report of Currently Not Collectible Taxes, for the (enter a mandatory follow-up date in item

approval. e. Document the ICS case history and annotate on Form

), Currently Not Collectible Procedures . Note: Please see IRM
, Requesting Currently Not Collectible Input for Assessed and Pre-assessed Tax Periods. (

) The revenue officer assigned the balance due account should determine re- sponsibility and willfulness for all potentially responsible persons, including U.S. citizens residing overseas and foreign nationals having no assets the United States. (
) If a potentially responsible officer resides overseas, the revenue officer will conduct an investigation to determine if there are any assets located within U.S. (

) If no assets are found, the revenue officer will initiate a Courtesy using the ICS Other Investigation (OI) process, to the office responsible for International Collection since recommendations for nonassertion of the for these cases are the responsibility of this office. (See IRM
, Investigations to International). (
) The revenue officer in International Collection assigned the OI will consider facts of the case and make a decision regarding assertion of the penalty upon treaty considerations. (
) If this revenue officer determines that there is no collection potential, he or should: a. Prepare Form

and forward it to his or her group manager for approval. b. Return the approved form, along with all related information, to the revenue officer who initiated the OI. Note: The revenue officer who initiated the OI will handle the final disposition. (
) If the revenue officer assigned the OI determines that the responsible will return to the United States in the future and collection may be possible, assertion of the penalty should be recommended.
If the present collection potential is minimal but future collection potential

exists: a. Recommend assertion of the TFRP for group manager approval. b. Advise the taxpayer that one notice will be sent reflecting the balance and a Notice of Federal Tax Lien will be filed, if appropriate. c. Prepare Form
, Report of Currently Not Collectible Taxes, for the (enter a mandatory follow-up date in item
if appropriate). d. Forward the entire package through the group manager for Form
approval. e. Document the ICS case history and annotate on Form
that Form was prepared. f. Process the TFRP assessment per IRM
, Taxpayer’s Response to Letter

Note: Please see IRM 5.16.1.4, Requesting Currently Not Collectible Input for Assessed and Pre-assessed Tax Periods.

The revenue officer assigned the balance due account should determine re- sponsibility and willfulness for all potentially responsible persons, including U.S. citizens residing overseas and foreign nationals having no assets the United States. If a potentially responsible officer resides overseas, the revenue officer will conduct an investigation to determine if there are any assets located within U.S. If no assets are found, the revenue officer will initiate a Courtesy using the ICS Other Investigation (OI) process, to the office responsible for International Collection since recommendations for nonassertion of the for these cases are the responsibility of this office. (See IRM

, Investigations to International). The revenue officer in International Collection assigned the OI will consider facts of the case and make a decision regarding assertion of the penalty upon treaty considerations. If this revenue officer determines that there is no collection potential, he or should: a. Prepare Form
and forward it to his or her group manager for approval. b. Return the approved form, along with all related information, to the revenue officer who initiated the OI.
(04-13-2006) Nonassertion of Trust Fund Recovery on Taxpayer Residing Overseas
Note: The revenue officer who initiated the OI will handle the final disposition.
